text:
Hi all! I’m a strategist at a marketing performance agency. We’re looking to expand our network of SEO freelancers for a variety of projects.

:clipboard: Projects might include technical & content audits, keyword research, link building, content strategy, overall SEO consulting, etc.
:pencil2: We are most interested in talent with expertise in *healthcare, education, e-commerce, real-estate, or tourism*
:white_check_mark: Most of all, we’re looking for trusted experts and partners we can call upon when projects pop-up.

Give me a shout if you’re interested in connecting and learning more. Thank you and I hope everyone has a fantastic Friday!

elements.text: Hi all! I’m a strategist at a marketing performance agency. We’re looking to expand our network of SEO freelancers for a variety of projects.
Projects might include technical & content audits, keyword research, link building, content strategy, overall SEO consulting, etc.
We are most interested in talent with expertise in
healthcare, education, e-commerce, real-estate, or tourism

Most of all, we’re looking for trusted experts and partners we can call upon when projects pop-up.

Give me a shout if you’re interested in connecting and learning more. Thank you and I hope everyone has a fantastic Friday!

text: One last question (I think haha): do you have a standard procedure you write in the contract for number of revisions for large projects with multiple pages?

elements.text: One last question (I think haha): do you have a standard procedure you write in the contract for number of revisions for large projects with multiple pages?

text: No more than 2 revisions! I also typically give them a date by which they need to use them by!

elements.text: No more than 2 revisions! I also typically give them a date by which they need to use them by!

text:
<@U02RGBRUUE8> so 2 rounds of revisions on 40 pages? I would obviously try to batch all revisions at once, so I'm not revising each for one at a time. 

Can you elaborate on giving them a date to use them by? What happens if they don't use your revision by a certain date?

elements.text: so 2 rounds of revisions on 40 pages? I would obviously try to batch all revisions at once, so I'm not revising each for one at a time.
Can you elaborate on giving them a date to use them by? What happens if they don't use your revision by a certain date?

text: I would also spell out what a revision is and make it clear that it’s not a re-write! Yeah, I would definitely batch it. So I usually give them a 2-week window after I submit drafts to request revisions, if they don’t get back to me within that time they forfeit the right to revisions!

elements.text: I would also spell out what a revision is and make it clear that it’s not a re-write! Yeah, I would definitely batch it. So I usually give them a 2-week window after I submit drafts to request revisions, if they don’t get back to me within that time they forfeit the right to revisions!

text:
Ok, that makes sense! Thank you. 

Another question arose (of course): Do you recommend breaking up the payment by phases, and/or half payment up front and half upon completion?

He's asking for a ballpark figure, so I was planning to email him and give him an informal breakdown—then write a formal proposal (and get a contract in place) once he agrees.

elements.text: Ok, that makes sense! Thank you.
Another question arose (of course): Do you recommend breaking up the payment by phases, and/or half payment up front and half upon completion?
He's asking for a ballpark figure, so I was planning to email him and give him an informal breakdown—then write a formal proposal (and get a contract in place) once he agrees.

text:
I typically do 50% upfront, and 50% at the 30-day mark. Anything over $25k, I let them know that I can offer a 4-part payment plan.

That sounds fine! I personally just do a formal proposal since it gives me the opportunity to re-state value before getting to the price. But I know Joanna Weibe from CopyHackers recommends getting an informal yes before sending proposals!

elements.text:

text: <https://kaitlynarford.com/about/>

attachments.text: Award-winning freelance journalist with experience writing all kinds of content.
attachments.title: About

text:
G’day all! I’m looking to hire an opinionated, voice-forward contract writer to help build the weekly <https://chatty.so/motormouth|Motormouth newsletter>! Here’s the rundown:

• :mega: We’ll be sharing a mix of curated freelance editorial gigs and original content centered around helping content managers/directors, agencies, and publishers tell better stories and create more compelling editorial content.
• :magnet: We’re a tiny team, so you’ll have a ton of editorial freedom to play with. We’ll work together to refine pitches (we _are_ an editorial service, after all), but we’d expect you to pitch most ideas you cover. Ideally you’ll have intimate knowledge of the content / brand journalism space, care deeply about great editorial, and enjoy a good (read: bad) writing pun.
• :toolbox: Regular projects will include writing a short intro to the newsletter, along with 1-2 short (~400wo) weekly tips, interviews, trend analyses, etc (a la <http://marketerhire.createsend.com/t/ViewEmailArchive/j/01139F060B232D762540EF23F30FEDED/C67FD2F38AC4859C/|Raisin Bread>) each week. We’re also accepting <https://chatty.so/pitch-motormouth|pitches for original content>, so some of the newsletter shorts will be excerpted from the blog. HUGE bonus if you can find sources to interview and/or curate a few interesting external links each week as well!
Sound like you? Flick me a DM!
